video:video.video:title: Coral Reefs
video:video.video:description: Coral reefs are the foundation of many marine ecosystems—and they are in danger.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Andrea Marshall: Queen of the Manta Rays
video:video.video:description: Mysteries surrounding these ocean giants are finally being solved, thanks to the unique research of 2013 National Geographic Emerging Explorer Andrea Marshall.The National Geographic Live! series brings thought-provoking presentations by today’s leading explorers, scientists, photographers, and performing artists right to your YouTube feed. Each presentation is filmed in front of a live audience at National Geographic headquarters in Washington, D.C. New clips air every Monday.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Trapping Tigers
video:video.video:description: The camera trap is one of the many tools photographer Steve Winter uses to catches spectacular images of India's endangered tigers.

video:video.video:title: Desert Flower
video:video.video:description: Desert Flower tells the inspiring true story of Waris Dirie, who was catapulted to fame and fortune as a high fashion model after running away from an arranged marriage at age 13. But after years of living a glamorous life, the past comes back to haunt her, and she must face the childhood trauma that forever changed her destiny.

video:video.video:title: Cat Spotlight
video:video.video:description: Get a closer look at our cuddly cat friends.

video:video.video:title: Mobile Technology and the Art of the Possible
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Emerging Explorer Ken Banks discusses finding low-tech, low-cost, high-impact solutions to developing world needs at the 2010 Explorers Symposium.

video:video.video:title: Turtle Dance
video:video.video:description: Green turtles gather near Dirty Rock, Roca Sucia, off Cocos Island's north coast.

video:video.video:title: I Didn't Know That: Can You Survive Quicksand?
video:video.video:description: Is it possible to survive being stuck in quicksand? Jonny Phillips risks life and limb to experience firsthand what it is like to slowly sink into quicksand—just a few feet away from an incoming tide.

video:video.video:title: Antarctic Ocean
video:video.video:description: The coldest, windiest place on Earth holds 60 percent of the fresh water on the planet. Recent expeditions to the Weddell Sea produced more than 700 new species, including giant carnivorous sponges.

video:video.video:title: Otter Madness
video:video.video:description: Meet a man whose roommates are a pair of river otters.

video:video.video:title: Tea Time in the Falklands
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler Contributing Editor Andrew Evans gets to sample the many pastries made by Robert and Lorraine McGill, bona fide Falkland sheep farmers and the longtime owners of Carcass Island.

video:video.video:title: Lions
video:video.video:description: Chris Johns describes photographing Kalahari lions and how it took him 12 years to capture how majestic they can be.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Greg Wilson: Cheetahs on the Run
video:video.video:description: Cinematographer Greg Wilson uses innovative motion picture technology to capture slow-motion images of cheetahs in action, helping us expand our understanding of cheetah biomechanics.

video:video.video:title: Yellowstone's Water "Secrets"
video:video.video:description: Even though Yellowstone borders no ocean, water plays an important role in its life, geography and beauty.

video:video.video:title: Panamanian Party Bus
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler contributing editor Andrew Evans is traveling by bus from Washington D.C. to Antarctica, and shot some footage of the last bus he took in North America, traveleing between Colón and Portobelo.

video:video.video:title: Cordoba Pizza
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler contributing editor Andrew Evans followed his nose to an authentic Argentine pizzeria in Cordoba.

video:video.video:title: Narwhal Tooth
video:video.video:description: Learn the truth behind a mystical creature that lives under the Arctic ice.

video:video.video:title: Penguin Overload
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Contributing Editor Andrew Evans found him self surrounded when he arrived in South Georgia. Hundreds of thousands of king penguins swarmed on the beach, and one in particular was quite interested in his boots.

video:video.video:title: Nudist Camp
video:video.video:description: It's Christmas time in Florida, a time when neighbors get together to share some holiday cheer. But at this Christmas party, some might say they share too much.

video:video.video:title: Slideshow: Island of Waterfalls~Continued
video:video.video:description: A few members of the Ocean Now team spent the afternoon shooting locations on Cocos for a documentary that will be made about the expedition.

video:video.video:title: Mutant All-Black Penguin Found
video:video.video:description: March 16, 2010, 2010—National Geographic Traveler contributing editor Andrew Evans recently spotted and filmed an all-black king penguin—a very rare mutant—on the sub-Antarctic island of South Georgia.

video:video.video:title: Making Snow for the Olympics
video:video.video:description: Jan. 17, 2014—A Michigan-based snowmaking company, SMI Snow Makers, is using the latest technology to create snow for the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi. Their machines create snow crystals that are like two-week-old snow from Mother Nature. But while Mother Nature takes hours or days to manufacture the crystals, SMI's machines make the snow in 3 to 15 seconds.

video:video.video:title: Cave of Spirits
video:video.video:description: Down a dim corridor...in a tiny, locked room...out of bounds to all but a tormented few, is the cave of spirits...a home for the dead and last hope for the possessed.

video:video.video:title: First-Ever Inclusion: Hope for Egypt's Nubians
video:video.video:description: Jan. 31, 2014—Egyptians this month overwhelmingly approved a referendum on a draft constitution that for the first time included mention of Nubians. Many Nubians were relocated for construction of the Aswan High Dam some 50 years ago, and they now hope they can return to their historic homeland by the Nile.

video:video.video:title: NASA's Ares I-X Rocket Launches
video:video.video:description: October 28, 2009—NASA this morning launched a prototype of its first new rocket in nearly 30 years. The Ares I-X is a precursor of the rocket that could launch humans back to the moon, and carry the shuttle's replacement spacecraft, Orion.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Jodi Cobb: What Is Beauty?
video:video.video:description: On assignment for National Geographic, photographer Jodi Cobb explores a universal question—what is beauty?

video:video.video:title: Final Ride on Wild China River?
video:video.video:description: April 23, 2009—An adventure ride down a section of China's Yangtze River could be the last before planned hydroelectric dams flood the rapids and alter the landscape.

video:video.video:title: Byrd Expedition
video:video.video:description: Join Admiral Richard E. Byrd in 1928 as he leads a team of explorers to the coldest continent on Earth to map the region and claim large tracts of Antarctica for the United States.

video:video.video:title: Buddhism Rebounds in Mongolia
video:video.video:description: January 4, 2008—After decades of persecution that began under Stalinist rule in the 1930s, Buddhism and monasteries are now on the rebound in Mongolia.

video:video.video:title: Tropical Frogs
video:video.video:description: Learn about the art of camouflage among tropical frogs.

video:video.video:title: Clean Getaway
video:video.video:description: Watch a dung beetle try to make a clean getaway with...dung?

video:video.video:title: Cameron Dive is an Exploration First
video:video.video:description: James Cameron's dive to the deepest point of the Marianna Trench joins other exploration 'firsts' in world history.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Sarah and Eric McNair-Landry: Kite-Skiing in the Arctic
video:video.video:description: An adventurous brother-sister team on a Nat Geo Young Explorers grant kite-ski over 2,000 miles through Canada's Arctic archipelago, fending off polar bears and coping with unfavorable winds and rugged ice along the way.

video:video.video:title: Mediterranean Cleanup
video:video.video:description: A program in Spain is cleaning up its marine ecosystems by stopping pollutants while they're still on land.

video:video.video:title: Gag Bag
video:video.video:description: More favorite humor photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Salt Flats
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler contributing editor Andrew Evans visits the Uyuni Salt Flats in Bolivia.

video:video.video:title: Travel
video:video.video:description: Some favorite travel photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Terracotta Warriors
video:video.video:description: Louis Mazzatenta describes being the first photographer to capture an artifact being unearthed.

video:video.video:title: Male Circumcision
video:video.video:description: The Eastern Cape Province of South Africa is home to the Xhosa people, one of the nation's largest tribes. They live in the modern world, but they maintain ancient customs—including one by which boys become men...and starts with pain.

video:video.video:title: Rome's Ancient Neighborhood
video:video.video:description: Meet the true Romans of Rome in the neighborhood of Trastevere.

video:video.video:title: On the Go
video:video.video:description: Some favorite transportation photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Pristine Islands to Be Protected
video:video.video:description: August 26, 2008—U.S. President George W. Bush has proposed marine national monuments around several U.S.-held islands in the Pacific Ocean. It could become the world's largest protected area.

video:video.video:title: Destination: Egypt, Pyramids
video:video.video:description: Egypt's ancient pyramids have left visitors awestruck for thousands of years, and continue to do so today.

video:video.video:title: The Importance of Pristine Coral Reefs
video:video.video:description: National Geographic's Ocean Now is a project to study the last healthy, undisturbed places in the ocean. Join Dr. Enric Sala and a team of scientists as they spend six weeks exploring the pristine waters of the southern Line Islands in the South Pacific.

video:video.video:title: Tornadoes, Lightning in Rare Video
video:video.video:description: April 3, 2009—As tornado season touches down in the U.S., see a high-tech tornado chaser's stunning footage of twisters—and of lightning as you've never seen it, in superslow motion. EDITOR'S NOTE: Tragically, Tim Samaras died in an Oklahoma tornado May 31st, 2013, along with his son Paul, and Carl Young, a frequent partner of Tim's. Read here for more on his death. And click here for a compilation of Tim's videos on National Geographic.

video:video.video:title: Cameron's Long Way Down: Mariana Trench
video:video.video:description: Seven miles is a long way down... more than a mile deeper than Mt. Everest is up. To reach the deepest part of the Mariana Trench, James Cameron will descend past some pretty amazing milestones. Here's a glimpse.

video:video.video:title: Bacteria-size Babies Among Ocean's Smallest Life
video:video.video:description: April 19, 2010—Baby animals, or larvae, virtually unknown to science join algae, burrowers, and bacteria among the hundreds of microbes found by the Census of Marine Life's ten-year study of the sea.

video:video.video:title: Duck Fetus Dinner
video:video.video:description: To many Westerners, Asia has more than its share of suspicious-looking foods. But it's a good bet that there's nothing as popular while at the same time as utterly shocking to outsiders. Could you eat the fetus of a duck...just days from hatching?

video:video.video:title: Coastal Cleanup
video:video.video:description: Each year, hundreds of thousands of volunteers gather to clean up coastlines around the world.

video:video.video:title: Shuttle Astronauts Space Walk
video:video.video:description: October 26, 2007—Discovery shuttle astronauts begin the difficult job of attaching an Italian-made module to the International Space Station. The project is expected to take ten days.

video:video.video:title: Gila Monster
video:video.video:description: A reptile expert tangles with the infamous gila monster.

video:video.video:title: Radical Reels: Miller’s Thriller: Ski BASE (Custom edit for the Radical Reels Tour)
video:video.video:description: USA, 2010, 6 minutesProduced and directed by: Darrell MillerWebsite: www.stormshow.comClassification: Parental Guidance - Coarse LanguageThe Jackson Hole backcountry is the spectacular site for some amazing ski BASE jumps!

video:video.video:title: Swinging From the Alcove
video:video.video:description: Yosemite's superclimbers hurl above the ground on a rope swing.

video:video.video:title: Intro
video:video.video:description: Are you happy? Thrive author Dan Buettner introduces the Thrive Challenge – 8 daily tips about simple things you can do to bring more fulfillment into your life.

video:video.video:title: Yale Returning Peru Artifacts
video:video.video:description: September 17, 2007—More than 4,000 artifacts, taken from Machu Picchu in Peru nearly a century ago, will be returned from their displays at Yale University.

video:video.video:title: Climbing: Safety Third
video:video.video:description: When climbers opt to climb without a rope, they lose the luxury of learning from mistakes. Backyard inventor Matt Maddaloni has engineered a few creative solutions to make the fringe activity of free soloing “safe.” Of course, safe is a relative term.

video:video.video:title: Birds
video:video.video:description: Some favorite bird photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: It Takes Two
video:video.video:description: Some favorite pairs photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Explosions May Save Wetlands
video:video.video:description: October 31, 2007—The Nature Conservancy has blasted through 1950s-era levees in the Williams River Delta in southern Oregon to save the wetlands and endangered fish species.

video:video.video:title: Where's Andrew? Inside the National Geographic Maps Division
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler's contributing editor Andrew Evans is preparing for his next big trip, and so he stopped by the National Geographic Maps division to learn how they create the maps they're famous for.

video:video.video:title: Musical Moments From Sochi, Russia
video:video.video:description: Moments of song and dance in Sochi show a city gearing up for the Winter Olympics. Photographer Thomas Dworzak captured these musical glimpses while on assignment for National Geographic magazine.

video:video.video:title: Stranded on Starbuck Part 2
video:video.video:description: The on-shore Ocean Now team receives supplies from the ship and will attempt to swim back to the ship in the morning.

video:video.video:title: Panama Golden Frog Threatened
video:video.video:description: October 15, 2007—Panama's golden frog is a symbol of good luck and prosperity. Now researchers are fighting to save the rare amphibian from a naturally occuring—and deadly—fungus.

video:video.video:title: "Prehistoric" Shark Seen Attacking Deep Bait
video:video.video:description: July 22, 2010—A sixgill shark—a species often referred to as prehistoric because of its resemblance to sharks living hundreds of millions of years ago—is seen biting on bait at a camera trap deep off Australia. It's part of a project to learn more about deep-sea creatures and possible correlations with human sight and brain development.

video:video.video:title: How Gulf Spill Estimates Got It So Wrong
video:video.video:description: June 23, 2011—Marine oil spills are usually measured by the amount of oil floating on the surface. But the BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico—from a deep-sea well required a different approach. Find out how one fluid-dynamics expert caused estimates to rise sharply practically overnight.

video:video.video:title: Diver "Vanishes" in Portal to Maya Underworld
video:video.video:description: June 30, 2010—Diving into natural pools in Belize in the quest for offerings from the ancient Maya, explorers found what's believed to be the country's first recorded fossilized remains. In the course of the expedition, one diver "disappeared" into the pool's floor.

video:video.video:title: Radical Reels: Concrete Dreams
video:video.video:description: Germany, 2011, 7 minutesProduced and directed by: Danny StrasserWebsite: www.danny-strasser.deClassification: GeneralBobtrack downhill skateboarding is a sport that didn't actually exist- until Danny Strasser began his tour of Europe's tracks.

video:video.video:title: Santeria
video:video.video:description: Santeria was brought to the New World by African slaves. They believe their deities are living things, with the same needs as other beings. But each one has the power to bring good luck...or misfortune.

video:video.video:title: Oil Spill Threatens Native American "Water" Village
video:video.video:description: June 8, 2010--The town of Grand Bayou, Louisiana, has no streets and no cars, just water and boats. And now the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico threatens the very existence of the Atakapa-Ishak Indians who live there. "We're facing the potential for cultural genocide," says one tribe member.

video:video.video:title: Jungle Isles
video:video.video:description: Discover the secrets of animal-made islands in the rain forest.

video:video.video:title: Surrogate Moms Boost Wallaby Births
video:video.video:description: September 24, 2009—To help save South Australia's rare black-footed wallaby, researchers are taking joeys from the wild and placing them in surrogate pouches, encouraging wild moms to trigger "backup" pregnancies.

video:video.video:title: Light Motif
video:video.video:description: Some favorite photos of light by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Polar Algae Forests Explored
video:video.video:description: March 23, 2010—In cold Antarctic waters, explorers are finding lush forests of giant, "bad tasting" seaweed and communities of rarely seen sea creatures.

video:video.video:title: One Ocean
video:video.video:description: Water flows from one sea habitat to another, connecting all the creatures that live within, to one ocean.

video:video.video:title: Cruising
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Contributing Editor Andrew Evans shoots some scenes from the deck of the National Geographic Explorer as it sails through the Antarctic Peninsula

video:video.video:title: Snow Falls on Mars
video:video.video:description: September 30, 2008— NASA's Phoenix Mars Lander has detected snow falling from Martian clouds, and its soil testing shows further evidence of the planet's watery past, scientists say.

video:video.video:title: Living in Tombs
video:video.video:description: Manila's North Cemetery is the city's largest, with 70 to 80 funerals a day, and more than one million buried here. For most, this would be a chilling place to visit. But to some Filipinos, this sea of tombs and bones is the place they call home.

video:video.video:title: Surf's Up
video:video.video:description: Some favorite surfing photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Portable Scanners "Read" Brains on the Go
video:video.video:description: August 1, 2013—Though EEG (Electroencephalography) has been around for decades, now, new technology allows us to detect and measure brain activity with a lightweight headset and mobile phone. National Geographic Emerging Explorer and entrepreneur Tan Le demonstrates how her company's EEG headset and software can be used for a variety of research purposes.

video:video.video:title: Cobra vs. Mongoose
video:video.video:description: How does a mongoose stand up to a cobra? You might be surprised at the outcome.

video:video.video:title: Connorcam
video:video.video:description: The inventor of Crittercam tests his camera out on his son.

video:video.video:title: Why Deep-Sea Creatures Glow
video:video.video:description: May 6, 2010—The mysteries of why and how many animals in the deep sea emit light, known as bioluminescence, continue to puzzle scientists studying the evolution of this natural glow.

video:video.video:title: Spiders Jump With Deadly Accuracy in Green Light
video:video.video:description: January 26, 2012—Researchers have discovered a unique visual attribute that jumping spiders use in attacking and catching prey. The arachnids use what is called image defocus-proven in part by videos that show spiders jumping with deadly accuracy in green light (and fumbling in red).

video:video.video:title: Whale of a Leap
video:video.video:description: What's causing killer whales to jump out of the water?

video:video.video:title: Island Hopping
video:video.video:description: Some favorite island photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Clay Eating Discouraged
video:video.video:description: November 8, 2007—Poverty and tradition drive some Haitians to eat cakes of clay, salt, and butter. Nutritionists fight local beliefs about the dish's merits.

video:video.video:title: Nautilus Live Summer 2012
video:video.video:description: This summer descend into the unknown. Follow Dr. Robert Ballard and his team as they explore the ocean on the E/V Nautilus. Watch live video 24 hours a day on NautilusLive.org.

video:video.video:title: Sub Sphere: What Protects Human Deep Divers?
video:video.video:description: When James Cameron dives to the lowest point of the Pacific's Mariana Trench, 36,000 feet of water pressure is bearing down on his sub, which feels like 13 cars weighing on each of his shoulders! But he's protected by sitting inside a 2 1/2 inch thick steel ball.

video:video.video:title: Cameron Dive Breaks Record
video:video.video:description: March 26, 2012---National Geographic Explorer-in-Residence James Cameron completed a record-breaking dive to the lowest point of the Mariana Trench. See scenes as Cameron's sub, DEEPSEA CHALLENGER, resurfaced, and Cameron emerged from the pilot's capsule around noon, local time (10 p.m. ET March 25th).

video:video.video:title: Where's Andrew? He's On His Way
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler contributing editor Andrew Evans is heading out on another epic journey, only we're not exactly sure where he's going. Follow him at his Twitter page www.twitter.com/wheresandrew and check in at Nationalgeographic.com for clues on where he's headed.

video:video.video:title: Sea Lions
video:video.video:description: David Doubilet discusses the role of light and the playfulness of sea lions.

video:video.video:title: Radical Reels: From the Inside Out (Custom edit for the Radical Reels Tour)
video:video.video:description: Canada, 2011, 13 minutesDirected by: Dylan Dunkerton, Kyle Norbraten, Curtis Robinson (The Coastal Crew)Produced by: Ian Dunn, Kyle Norbraten, Darcy WittenburgWebsite: http://www.fromtheinsideout.secondbasefilms.comClassification: General - Coarse Language A partnership between standard setting Anthill Films and the progressive riders of The Coastal Crew, this is a freeride mountain biking film from the athletes themselves.

video:video.video:title: Yale Agrees to Return Machu Picchu Artifacts
video:video.video:description: September 20, 2007—Yale University has agreed to return thousands of Machu Picchu relics to the government of Peru in what many officials are hailing as a landmark deal.

video:video.video:title: Radical Reels: Here We Go Again (Custom edit for the Radical Reels Tour)
video:video.video:description: USA, 2010, 10 minutesDirected by: Don Hampton and Gardy RaymondProduced by: Don HamptonWebsite: www.dh-productions.comClassification: GeneralDH Production's twenty-fifth film adventure showcases their DIY style and blue collar work ethic. No matter where you're at or who you are, it's all about having fun on the bike.

video:video.video:title: On Board the Explorer
video:video.video:description: National Geographic Traveler contributing editor Andrew Evans gives a tour of his cabin on board the MV National Geographic Explorer, which is sailing through Antarctica.

video:video.video:title: Shuttle Docks With Station
video:video.video:description: June 2, 2008—The NASA space shuttle Discovery docked with the International Space Station Monday, bringing a huge new Japanese lab.

video:video.video:title: Dive at Dirty Rock
video:video.video:description: A few members of the Ocean Now team go for a dive at Dirty Rock near Cocos Island.

video:video.video:title: Exxon Valdez Lessons Applied in Gulf Coast Cleanup
video:video.video:description: December 3, 2010---Cleanup techniques used after the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill may have caused more environmental damage than the oil itself. So different strategies—such as washing sand and returning it to beaches—are helping to clean Gulf of Mexico coasts affected by the oil spill.

video:video.video:title: Explorer's Club Dinner
video:video.video:description: Once a year, the Big Apple hosts a unique dinner —the annual gala of the Explorer's Club. The highlight of the evening is the cocktail hour, where the finger food might have legs, a face, or even a tongue.

video:video.video:title: Peru With a View
video:video.video:description: After days of lush green banana plantations and tropical lowland jungle, Andrew Evans entered the Sechura Desert–one of the driest places on earth. The vegetation disappeared completely and what started as a bare sandy horizon soon transformed into a flowing wall of dramatic sand dunes on either side. "I felt like I’d been dropped into the world’s biggest sand box and as I watched out the window, the wind blew the sand into new drifts and patterns," he said.
